results_summary: Exercise, including walking, generally improved fertility outcomes in females with obesity, though the specific type, intensity, and duration of exercise varied widely across studies. Cyclic exercises like walking were commonly used, but optimal prescription details remain unclear.
population_specificity: Females with obesity experiencing infertility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess fall risk predictors and explore their association with FRAX scores in Turkish postmenopausal osteoporotic patients.
results_summary: The study found that patients with fragility fractures had poorer performance in fall prediction tests, and FRAX scores were higher in those with impaired balance tests, suggesting a link between fall risk and fracture risk.
population_specificity: Turkish women with postmenopausal osteoporosis (209 participants, mean age 67.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the need for on-demand, rapid-onset, short-duration drug-induced voiding therapies for individuals with neurologic injury or disease and elderly populations.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss findings related to Walking; it focuses on bladder and bowel dysfunction and potential therapies for voiding.
population_specificity: Individuals with neurologic injury (spinal cord injury, traumatic brain injury, stroke) or disease (multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, spina bifida) and many elderly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether baseline visual acuity (VA) is associated with an increased risk of all and injurious falls over 3 years in generally healthy older adults.
results_summary: Decreased VA at baseline was associated with a 22% increased incidence rate of all falls and a 20% increased incidence rate of injurious falls over 3 years, highlighting its role as an independent predictor of fall risk.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 70 years and older without major health events in the prior 5 years, sufficient mobility, and good cognitive status.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on visual acuity, not walking dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how interrupting prolonged sitting with different muscle activity patterns affects postprandial glycemic response.
results_summary: The study examined the effects of interrupting prolonged sitting on glycemic response in overweight and obese men, suggesting that muscle activity patterns may influence postprandial glucose levels.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese men (21.0 ± 1.2 years; 28.8 ± 2.2 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the 6- and 12-month safety of umbilical cord-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (UC-MSCs) in patients with SARS-CoV-2-induced acute respiratory distress syndrome.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in adverse effects or endpoints between UC-MSCs and placebo groups at 6 and 12 months. Some patients had persistent lung abnormalities and impaired quality of life, but no severe adverse effects were observed.
population_specificity: Patients with SARS-CoV-2-related early mild-to-severe acute respiratory distress syndrome.
study_duration: Follow-up at 6 and 12 months post-hospital discharge

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 12-week group-based exercise intervention, including vestibular and balance exercises, on dizziness, walking balance, and sarcopenia in older colorectal cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it aims to assess the maintenance of walking balance and lower limb strength/endurance at 12 weeks using Dynamic Gait Index and 30-Second Sit-to-Stand Test, with results analyzed via mixed linear regression.
population_specificity: Older patients (≥65 years) with colorectal cancer initiating (neo)adjuvant or first-line palliative chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Exercise three times/week (specific intensity/details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare laboratory gait measures and free-living step-based metrics between individuals with femoroacetabular impingement syndrome (FAIS) and uninjured controls to understand differences in walking characteristics.
results_summary: The study found no differences in laboratory gait measures between FAIS and control groups, but FAIS participants took fewer daily steps, had lower peak cadences, and spent less time in various walking cadence bands compared to uninjured controls.
population_specificity: 25 participants with FAIS and 14 uninjured controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if poor health status and low exercise tolerance (measured via walking tests) are associated with worse clinical characteristics in COPD patients and to develop a diagnostic model for these conditions.
results_summary: COPD patients with both poor health status and low exercise tolerance showed worse clinical outcomes, including higher dyspnea, severe obstruction, and longer sit-to-stand times. The diagnostic model demonstrated good internal validation for identifying these patients.
population_specificity: 208 stable COPD patients with FEV1/FVC < 0.7, ≥10 pack-year smoking history, and chronic respiratory symptoms.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking test performance measured, not a dosage intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify patient, surgical, and hospital factors associated with Day-1 postoperative mobility after hip fracture surgery in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that 49% of patients mobilized on Day-1 post-surgery, with lower odds of mobilization linked to pre-existing mobility aids, impaired cognition, aged care facility residence, higher anesthesia grades, surgery delays >48 hours, and restricted weight-bearing status. Reducing time to surgery was suggested as a potential quality improvement measure.
population_specificity: Older adults aged >50 years who underwent hip fracture surgery in Australia and New Zealand in 2020.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the efficacy of protein-enriched soup combined with weekly exercise on muscle health and metabolism in middle-aged and older adults with suboptimal protein intake.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved physical performance (e.g., 6-min walking distance, sit-to-stand time, grip strength), lipid profile (reduced triglycerides, increased HDL-C), and DHEA-S levels, while controls showed no such benefits.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults (mean age 64.65 ± 4.84 years, 81.8% female) with insufficient protein intake (<1.0 g/kg/day).
effective_dosage: 24-30 g protein daily via protein-enriched soup, plus 1-hour weekly exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the recovery of physical activity (walking) post-lung resection in non-small cell lung cancer patients and assess the impact of age and surgical procedure on this recovery.
results_summary: Walking steps increased significantly until day 4 post-surgery, then plateaued. Age correlated with step count after day 4, and thoracotomy reduced steps compared to video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with non-small cell lung cancer who underwent lung resection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between serum PM20D1 levels and clinical parameters, including 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), in idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH) patients.
results_summary: The study found that IPAH patients with poor prognosis had significantly decreased 6MWD, and PM20D1 was positively correlated with 6MWD. Lower 6MWD was also identified as a risk factor for mortality in IPAH patients.
population_specificity: 103 IPAH patients enrolled from January 2018 to January 2022.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pressure and stiffness of a new compression device for regulating pressure during walking and other physical activities in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The device showed good correlation with expected pressure ranges and demonstrated stiffness indices comparable to inelastic bandages, suggesting potential hemodynamic effectiveness. It was also reported as very easy to apply and use.
population_specificity: 30 healthy volunteers (60 legs).

study_goal: The study does not investigate Walking; it focuses on pirfenidone's effects on mild-to-moderate idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.
results_summary: The study does not report any findings related to Walking.
population_specificity: Adult patients with mild-to-moderate idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different protein supplements on muscle mass, strength, and mobility outcomes in middle-aged and older individuals undergoing resistance training.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation was found to be the most effective in augmenting resistance training outcomes, significantly improving muscle mass, handgrip strength, and walking speed compared to other protein sources. Health condition, sex, and supplementation dose were identified as moderating factors for treatment efficacy.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older individuals, including untrained community-dwelling adults, hospitalized, or institutionalized residents with acute or chronic health conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of wearable lower limb exoskeletons (LLEs) on enhancing physical function and intrinsic capacities in older adults, aligning with the WHO's healthy aging vision.
results_summary: The systematic review found that LLE interventions improved functional abilities in older adults with various health conditions, though the abstract does not specify the magnitude or statistical significance of these improvements. The study covered diverse LLE technologies and intervention durations.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65+ with health conditions such as sarcopenia, stroke, Parkinson's Disease, and osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether microalgae extract containing fucoxanthin, combined with a diet and exercise program, could enhance weight loss, fat loss, and other health metrics in overweight females.
results_summary: The study found that fucoxanthin supplementation did not promote additional weight or fat loss but improved bone mass, bone density, walking steps/day, resting heart rate, aerobic capacity, blood lipid profiles, diet adherence, functional activity tolerance, and quality of life.
population_specificity: Overweight but otherwise healthy females (28.6 ± 7.9 years, 80.2 ± 14.9 kg, 29.6 ± 3.8 kg/m², 41.4 ± 4.2% fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether wearing vibrating insoles for the first time improves balance, walking, and ankle-foot muscle activity in people with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN).
results_summary: Vibrating insoles reduced center of pressure sway during standing balance on foam surfaces with eyes closed and decreased EMG amplitude in soleus and medial gastrocnemius muscles during balance tests, suggesting improved balance and altered muscle activity. However, the effects were small with uncertain clinical significance.
population_specificity: 18 ambulant men and women diagnosed with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN).
effective_dosage: Not specified (vibrating insoles worn during testing sessions).
study_duration: Two separate testing sessions (one per insole type).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare daily activity performance (including walking) in stroke survivors between inpatient rehabilitation and home environments at discharge.
results_summary: Activity scores for walking were significantly worse at home compared to inpatient rehabilitation, with over 40% of participants showing moderate-to-complete impairment at home despite no-to-mild impairment scores at discharge. The study highlights the impact of environment on functional performance.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors aged ≥50 discharging home from inpatient rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether overground gait training with a safety suspension device accelerates the achievement of supervision-level walking in subacute stroke patients compared to conventional assisted-gait training.
results_summary: The safety suspension-device group reached a FAC score of 3 in a median of 7 days, significantly faster than the control group's 17.5 days, with a higher probability of achieving the goal after adjusting for age and motor impairment.
population_specificity: Twenty-seven patients with subacute stroke and a FAC score of 2 at admission.
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per day, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether extracorporeal shockwave therapy improves quality of life and walking function in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly improved pain-free and maximum walking distances at 12 weeks, though the primary quality-of-life improvement did not remain significant after adjusting for covariates. The study suggests shockwave therapy may be a safe, noninvasive alternative for managing claudication.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication who refused or were unable to participate in supervised exercise, excluding those on anticoagulation therapy or with active cancer.
effective_dosage: 100 impulses of 0.1mJ/mm/cm², 3 times weekly for 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of sitting Baduanjin exercises on cardiovascular and psychosocial functions in patients with STEMI following PCI.
results_summary: The intervention group showed improved heart rate variability, lower anxiety and depression scores, and greater exercise capacity (6-MWD) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with ST-segment elevation acute myocardial infarction (STEMI) following percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
effective_dosage: Daily sitting Baduanjin training in addition to seven-step rehabilitation exercises (control group received only the seven-step rehabilitation training, twice daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how frailty status modifies the effects of various interventions, including walking, in older adults.
results_summary: Walking, either alone or combined with nutrition, produced similar intervention effects across different frailty levels, while other non-pharmacological interventions showed varying benefits based on frailty. Functional walking demonstrated greater benefits in patients with higher frailty levels.
population_specificity: Older adults with varying degrees of frailty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of tiotropium bromide in patients with bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS) using spirometry and a 6-minute walking test as measurements.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results regarding the effects of walking; it focuses on the ongoing evaluation of tiotropium bromide for BOS.
population_specificity: 20 patients with bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the effects of overground locomotor training on walking turns in individuals with mild Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects on intersegmental coordination but observed moderate improvements in frontal plane dynamic postural stability during walking turns. Small effects were noted in the transverse plane, though these were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild Parkinson's disease (12 participants, 7 males/5 females, mean age 68.5 ± 6.4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, safety, and acceptability of a home-based motor-cognitive eHealth exercise intervention for people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The intervention was safe, with no adverse events reported, and showed high adherence (86% of sessions completed). Participants rated most sessions as enjoyable, and the exertion level was light, suggesting suitability for mild-to-moderate PD patients.
population_specificity: People with mild-to-moderate Parkinson's disease (mean age 68.5 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercises were individually adapted and progressed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a 12-week home-based exercise program (HBEP) for people with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD) and determine its acceptability and preliminary effects on walking outcomes.
results_summary: The HBEP was feasible and well tolerated, with good recruitment and minimal attrition. Adherence to step goals was moderate (53.5%), and small clinically important improvements were observed in walking speed and pain-free treadmill walking distance, though no significant differences were found in exploratory outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication due to peripheral artery disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: Personalized step goals and a twice-weekly resistance-based circuit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the applications, protocols, and clinical recommendations for plantar pressure measurement systems in assessing foot function during standing and walking.
results_summary: The study found that rigid pressure platforms are most accurate for measuring plantar pressures during barefoot walking, while in-shoe systems are better suited for dynamic movements and assessing footwear effects. It highlighted the need for improved calibration procedures and the potential of AI in data analysis.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of measurement systems)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether active workstations (including walking) could reduce sedentary behavior without impairing cognitive performance or fine motor skills in office workers.
results_summary: Active workstations, including walking, improved cognitive performance compared to sitting, with no reported impairment in work performance (typing speed and accuracy).
population_specificity: Healthy office workers (n=44, 64% women, mean age 35±11 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved using a walking workstation during office work).
study_duration: 4 consecutive days (one day per workstation type).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if loading the upper limbs with external weights during walking could improve walking speed, trunk control, and balance in ambulatory children with hemiplegic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Both the intervention and control groups showed significant improvements in gait speed, trunk control, and balance, but the intervention group (with upper limb loading) demonstrated greater improvements compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Ambulatory children with hemiplegic cerebral palsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish clinical practice guidelines for using 3D-IGA to assess and inform interventions for walking in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study concluded that 3D-IGA is useful for identifying gait deviations, informing surgical and non-surgical interventions, and evaluating intervention effectiveness, supported by evidence-based action statements.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy who walk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of gait speed (measured via a 6-minute walk test) on clinical outcomes after crural and pedal bypass in patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI).
results_summary: The study found that patients with higher gait speed (>288 m in 6MWT) had better survival, graft patency, limb salvage, wound healing, and fewer major adverse cardiovascular events compared to those with lower gait speed (≤288 m). The LG group (lower gait speed) was older, suggesting age may influence outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) who underwent crural and pedal bypass.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (gait speed measured, not a dosage).
study_duration: 6-minute walk test performed at 1 month post-bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the 355 nm laser atherectomy system for treating infrainguinal arterial disease in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that the 355 nm laser system was safe (95.1% of subjects did not experience periprocedural major adverse events) and effective (69.0% achieved technical procedural success with improved ABI, Rutherford, and WIQ scores at 6 and 12 months).
population_specificity: Patients with infrainguinal PAD, including those with de novo, re-stenotic, and in-stent restenosis lesions (mean age 68.4 years, 61.8% male, 44.6% with critical limb ischemia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the association between daily step counts and multiple health outcomes in a healthy population.
results_summary: Increasing daily step counts was negatively correlated with metabolic outcomes, cardiovascular diseases, all-cause mortality, and improvements in postural balance, cognitive function, and mental health. However, no association was found between outdoor walking and improvements in systolic or diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Healthy population across different age groups, countries, and cohorts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of using force-sensing insoles to measure daily limb loading metrics (peak force, impulse, and loading rate) in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that force-sensing insoles were feasible for capturing real-world limb loading, with high recruitment (77.3%), adherence (7.4 hours/day wear time), data usability (87.8%), and participant satisfaction (80.5%). Metrics like peak force, impulse, and loading rate were 100% usable in controlled settings.
population_specificity: Older adults participating in a weight loss and bone health intervention.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (wearable technology, not a supplement).
study_duration: 6 months (with insole use during month two for 4 days, 8 hours/day).

study_goal: To examine whether interrupting prolonged sitting with short, frequent, light-intensity walking improves postprandial cardiovascular markers in people with type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that interrupting sitting with light walking attenuated postprandial increases in vascular-inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-1β, PAI-1, fibrinogen) compared to prolonged sitting, with enhanced effects in insulin-resistant individuals.
population_specificity: 32 adults with type 1 diabetes (mean age 28 ± 5 years, 17 women).
effective_dosage: 3-minute bouts of self-paced walking every 30 minutes, starting 1 hour after each meal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on nurse-led physical activity interventions, including walking, for people with dementia in nursing homes and identify facilitators and barriers to sustainable implementation.
results_summary: Outdoor or walking activities showed an overall positive impact on physical outcomes for people with dementia, though effects were inconclusive for other types of interventions. Barriers and facilitators to implementation included staff shortages and time resources (barriers) and ease of implementation and adaptability (facilitators).
population_specificity: People with dementia living in nursing homes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether stored iron levels influence the adaptive response to Nordic walking (NW) training combined with time-restricted eating (TRE) in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that NW + TRE significantly reduced ferritin levels, with greater reductions in the low ferritin group. It also lowered HbA1c and glucose levels, with more pronounced HbA1c drops in those with greater ferritin decreases. The high ferritin group showed greater improvements in body weight and fat percentage.
population_specificity: Older adults divided into low ferritin (<75 ng/ml) and high ferritin (≥75 ng/ml) groups.
effective_dosage: 12-week Nordic walking training combined with 10-hour time-restricted eating.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a home-based exercise programme (HBEP) and a centre-based exercise (CBE) on functional capacity, peripheral muscle oxygenation, and quality of life in individuals with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a comparison between HBEP and CBE, focusing on functional capacity, muscle oxygenation, and quality of life, but results are not yet reported as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Individuals with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: Intermittent walking until claudication symptoms, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the symptoms, diagnostic methods, pathophysiology, and treatment options for Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness (PPPD), particularly its exacerbation by walking and other factors.
results_summary: The study found that PPPD symptoms, including dizziness and unsteadiness, are worsened by walking, upright posture, motion, and complex visual stimuli. Diagnostic tests like the head roll-tilt subjective visual vertical test and gaze stability test may help identify PPPD, and treatments include SSRIs/SNRIs, vestibular rehabilitation, and cognitive behavioral therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with PPPD, predominantly around 50 years of age, with a female predominance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of home-based exercise (HBE) versus center-based exercise (CBE), and their combination, on patient-reported and performance-based outcomes in people with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in short-term pain, physical disability, walking ability, and lower limb muscle strength between HBE and CBE. Combining HBE with CBE may enhance overall efficacy.
population_specificity: People with knee osteoarthritis (956 participants across 11 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to consolidate existing literature on intramedullary meningiomas, a rare spinal tumor subtype, to improve clinical decision-making and understanding of diagnostic and therapeutic approaches.
results_summary: The study found that intramedullary meningiomas present with symptoms like difficulty walking, sensory disturbances, and urinary incontinence, and surgical interventions, particularly total resection, often yield favorable outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with intramedullary meningiomas (a rare spinal tumor subtype).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare energy expenditure (EE) between ground and water environments in individuals with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) while maintaining a sitting posture.
results_summary: The study measured variables like oxygen consumption, heart rate, and respiratory metrics during sitting on ground and in water, but the abstract does not report specific findings regarding walking or comparative outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (postural assessment, not a dosage-based intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test mediators and moderators of a walking intervention's benefits for preventing neck pain in high-risk office workers.
results_summary: The study found that exceeding recommended step counts on more days mediated the walking intervention's benefits for reducing neck pain risk, while no moderators showed significant effects. The intervention was similarly effective across different worker groups.
population_specificity: Office workers at high risk for developing neck pain (n=91).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic use of botulinum toxin in children and adolescents with cerebral palsy, focusing on its indications, efficacy, and safety profile.
results_summary: The study found that botulinum toxin was safe and effective in reducing spasticity, improving gait and upper limb function, facilitating hygiene care, reducing pain, preventing musculoskeletal deformities, and decreasing sialorrhea, particularly when administered by a multidisciplinary rehabilitation team.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 0-18 years with cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between phase angle (PhA) and postoperative clinical outcomes, including walking speed and motor function, in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: PhA was significantly correlated with improved Japanese Orthopedic Association (JOA) scores, walking speed, and Timed Up and Go test results at all postoperative assessment points, suggesting it may be a useful clinical indicator after LSS surgery.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent surgical treatment for clinically and radiologically defined lumbar spinal stenosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the current biomechanics of sacroiliac joints in relation to physiological and pathological conditions, particularly focusing on their role in upright bipedal walking.
results_summary: The study found that sacroiliac joint motion is minimal (<1 mm) and similar in both physiological and pathological states, with joint structures optimized for shock absorption during walking. However, the relationship between joint morphology and pain remains unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified (general biomechanical review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a theory-driven app-based intervention with behavioral support to promote brisk walking (a form of MVPA) in people living with and beyond cancer.
results_summary: The trial procedures were found to be acceptable, with high retention (97%) and assessment completion rates (>86%). The intervention was feasible, with 96% app download rates in the intervention group, supporting progression to a phase III trial.
population_specificity: People diagnosed with breast, prostate, or colorectal cancer recruited from a single UK hospital site.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included the NHS 'Active 10' app, print materials, and two behavioral support calls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of early mobilisation (standing, walking) compared to no mobilisation on pathophysiological and functional outcomes in animals with induced spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: Early mobilisation within 14 days of SCI was associated with greater Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor levels and statistically significant functional gains, with the greatest improvements seen when mobilisation began within 3 days or at low intensity. Confidence in the findings was low to moderate due to risk of bias and mixed methodological quality.
population_specificity: Rats and mice with induced spinal cord injury.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mobilisation intensity and timing varied).
study_duration: Mobilisation initiated within 14 days of injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess postoperative functional capacity, including the effects of prehabilitation (which involved walking tests like the 6MWT) in colorectal cancer surgery patients, particularly those without postoperative complications.
results_summary: Prehabilitation improved postoperative functional capacity, as evidenced by better performance in tests like the 6-minute walking test (6MWT), even in patients without complications. The study suggests multimodal prehabilitation, including walking, enhances recovery.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer surgery patients (n=251).
effective_dosage: Not specified (prehabilitation included various functional capacity tests).
study_duration: Assessments at baseline (T0) and 4 weeks postoperatively (T3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether morning or evening moderate-intensity walking had different effects on glucose levels in people with type 2 diabetes taking metformin.
results_summary: Morning walking acutely lowered glucose levels compared to baseline, particularly when metformin was taken before breakfast. No significant differences were found between morning and evening walking at specific time points, but the combination of morning exercise and pre-breakfast metformin persistently reduced glucose levels.
population_specificity: 18 adults (9 males, 9 females) with type 2 diabetes on metformin monotherapy, aged 61 ± 8.2 years.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of walking at 70% of estimated max heart rate every other day.
interactions: Interaction noted between morning exercise and timing of metformin intake (before vs. after breakfast).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of biomechanical devices (Foot Orthoses, Ankle Orthoses, and Taping) on gait and muscle activity in individuals with ankle instability.
results_summary: Biomechanical device therapy improved gait parameters (swing time, stance time, step) and reduced plantar flexion, inversion, and motion variability. It also enhanced muscle activity in specific lower limb muscles.
population_specificity: Individuals with ankle instability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of early denosumab administration after femoral intertrochanteric fracture surgery and compare its effect on fracture healing to ibandronate-treated patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in fracture healing rates between denosumab and ibandronate groups, as assessed by physical findings, plain radiographs, and CT scans at 3 months postoperatively. Walking ability showed no significant differences between the two groups.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent surgery for intertrochanteric femoral fragility fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of comorbidities, assessed using the Charlson comorbidity index (CCI), on postoperative walking independence in elderly patients with hip fractures.
results_summary: The study found that the CCI was significantly associated with postoperative walking independence, with a hazard ratio of 0.40 (95% CI, 0.189-0.865), indicating that higher comorbidity burden reduced the likelihood of regaining walking independence. The analysis adjusted for age, operative delay, and nutritional status.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with hip fractures who were able to walk independently before the incident (FIM walk score ≥6 points).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare brain neuroplasticity, walking performance, and quality of life between individuals using a new passive ankle prosthesis versus a standard passive prosthesis, and to assess changes in walking movement patterns.
results_summary: The study protocol was designed to evaluate differences in brain neuroplasticity via MRI, walking performance, and quality of life over a 24-week period, but results were not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with unilateral transtibial amputation and a control group of able-bodied individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week telecoaching intervention could improve physical activity, physical fitness, and quality of life in patients with interstitial lung disease (ILD).
results_summary: The study found that the telecoaching intervention did not significantly improve physical activity (step count), physical fitness, or quality of life in ILD patients compared to usual care.
population_specificity: Patients with interstitial lung disease (ILD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included a step counter, smartphone app, and coaching calls).

study_goal: The abstract does not address Walking; it focuses on Yoga Nidra's effects on postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Walking.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and cost effectiveness of surgical fixation versus non-surgical management for lateral compression type-1 pelvic fractures in older adults to determine which treatment leads to better recovery.
results_summary: The trial closed early due to low recruitment, preventing any conclusive results. Most patients were ineligible because they could mobilize independently shortly after injury, and the study could not answer the research question.
population_specificity: Patients aged 60+ with lateral compression type-1 pelvic fractures from low-energy falls, unable to mobilize independently due to pain 72 hours post-injury.
study_duration: 6 months follow-up planned, but trial ended early.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of interval walking training (IWT) in improving physical fitness, muscle strength, and glycemic control, particularly in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: IWT was found to improve physical fitness, muscle strength, and glycemic control in individuals with type 2 diabetes by enhancing glucose effectiveness. However, long-term adherence remains a challenge, especially in populations with chronic diseases or overweight/obesity.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes and populations with chronic diseases or overweight/obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the development of locomotion in infants, focusing on both gait (form) and mobility (function), and how these aspects integrate to enable functional movement.
results_summary: The study found that infant locomotion improves with experience, highlighting individual solutions for mobility and the cascading impact of movement on other developmental domains. It critiques the traditional focus on milestones, emphasizing functional mobility instead.
population_specificity: Infants (developmental focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effectiveness of oligopeptide nutrition preparation combined with exercise (including walking as part of aerobic exercise) in improving muscle strength and function in older adults with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found that oral peptide nutrition and exercise interventions improved grip strength and walking speed but did not increase muscle mass. The combined intervention maintained leg fat-free mass, unlike other groups where it decreased.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged 65+) with sarcopenia in a community setting.
effective_dosage: Exercise intervention included 60 minutes of training (warm-up, resistance, and aerobic exercise) 5 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of preparatory strength/plyometric training versus walking on running kinematics in novice female runners.
results_summary: Both walking and plyometric training groups showed similar changes in running kinematics, with improved sagittal plane biomechanics (more extended leg during swing) after training, which may relate to better running economy. No significant differences were found between the two preparatory training methods.
population_specificity: 57 novice female runners
study_duration: 16 weeks total (8 weeks preparatory training + 8 weeks running)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation (PNF) techniques on respiratory parameters, swallowing, functional capacity, fatigue, and quality of life in people with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: PNF techniques improved respiratory muscle strength, respiratory functions, cough efficiency, swallowing functions, and quality of life in mild to moderate PwMS, though improvements were not superior except for %FEV1.
population_specificity: People with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS), mean ages 43.23±10.55 (PNF Group) and 38.47±8.18 (Control Group).
effective_dosage: PNF techniques applied three days per week for eight weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with vitamin D3 or omega-3 fatty acids improved physical performance measures, including walking speed, in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no improvement in walking speed or other physical performance measures with either vitamin D3 or omega-3 supplementation compared to placebo. All groups showed worsening walking speeds and TUG over the 2-year period.
population_specificity: Generally healthy US adults (men ≥50 and women ≥55 years) from a New England subcohort.
effective_dosage: Vitamin D3 (2000 IU/day) and/or marine omega-3 fatty acids (1 g/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare knee kinematics between asymmetric and symmetric posterior-stabilized total knee arthroplasty (TKA) designs during step-up and lunge motions.
results_summary: The study found that both TKA designs exhibited comparable knee kinematics, with the symmetric design showing a slightly larger range of femoral axial rotation during lunge. The functionality of the asymmetric design was expected to be similar to its precursor symmetric design.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent TKA (16 TKAs from each treatment group) and did not use walking aids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of physical activity in individuals with lower limb loss, focusing on physical and psychosocial factors.
results_summary: The study found that community mobility (Life Space Assessment) and physical performance (Short Physical Performance Battery) were significant predictors of physical activity, accounting for 25% of the variance. Male participants had lower physical activity scores compared to females.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling prosthetic ambulators with unilateral transtibial or transfemoral amputation (N = 72, 86% male, average age 65).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of the DeFOG-system, which delivers personalized auditory cues, on alleviating freezing of gait (FOG) in people with Parkinson's disease (PD) during daily life and under different medication states.
results_summary: The study found that DeFOG reduced FOG considerably in severe freezers both off and on medication, with an effect size of d = 0.57, and combining DeFOG with medication yielded an effect size of d = 0.67. However, 4 weeks of DeFOG-use in daily life did not improve FOG during the protocol unless DeFOG was actively worn.
population_specificity: People with Parkinson's disease (PD) and daily freezing of gait (FOG) (n=63).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of dry needling (DN) and extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) in treating plantar fasciitis (PF), focusing on pain relief and functional improvement.
results_summary: Both DN and ESWT significantly improved pain (VAS), function (FFI), and walking/standing metrics (Max PfST, Max PfWD). DN showed superior improvements in VAS-activity and FFI-disability compared to ESWT, with trends favoring DN in other measures.
population_specificity: 55 patients with plantar fasciitis.
study_duration: Assessments at baseline, post-treatment first week, and fourth week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term and long-term efficacy of three falls-prevention programs (two land-based and one water-based) in improving physical outcome measures associated with falls-risk in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that both land-based and water-based falls-prevention programs improved physical outcome measures like Timed-Up-and-Go (TUG) and walking speed, with some improvements maintained at six-month follow-up. The high-level land-based program showed the most consistent improvements, though all programs demonstrated benefits.
population_specificity: Older adults participating in falls-prevention programs.
study_duration: Duration of the intervention was not explicitly stated, but follow-up assessments were conducted post-program and at six months.
